title: XPO Logistics Earnings Slide in Weaker Freight Market
summary: Declining revenue and profit at North American logistics provider come amid tepid reports on shipping demand. XPO Logistics Inc.'s adjusted diluted earnings per share declined in the first quarter, beating expectations as revenue fell back in a weakening North American freight market and the company coped with the loss of business from Amazon.com Inc.

title: uBiome CEOs Go on Leave After FBI Search

title: A Real Attorney General

title: House Suspends Deadline for Banks to Hand Over Trump Documents

summary: Stock is down 13% this year through Wednesday's close. Eventbrite Inc. shares fell about 29% during after-hours trading Wednesday after the company posted a wider-than-expected first-quarter loss and gave a disappointing forecast for the current quarter.

summary: The attack on political freedom in Hong Kong could sap the vitality that made it the world's envy.. But I cannot ignore the erosion of freedom in what was once one of Asia's freest cities: Hong Kong.

title: The Afghan Endgame Has Become Surreal
summary: American negotiators are coddling the Taliban while declaring an allied official persona non grata.. The U.S. no longer sees victory as a possibility in Afghanistan. Political and military leaders are now focused on getting out with a facade of honor. This has created a surreal situation: The U.S. is negotiating directly with the Taliban, the enemy it sought to remove from power almost 18 years ago. These "peace" talks are going on even as the Taliban has started its spring offensive. To add to the absurdity, the Afghan government, America's own creation, has been excluded from the negotiations because the Taliban, our common enemy, demanded it. American leaders seem oblivious to their culpability for the deteriorating situation.

title: The Complicated Truth About Vaccines
summary: They can appear to be the proximate cause of a condition when they have nothing to do with the ultimate cause.. Why are people afraid of vaccines? title: UC Berkeley's Emi Nakamura Wins John Bates Clark Medal
summary: Ms. Nakamura is just fourth woman to receive award since it began in 1947. title: 'The Adjunct Underclass' Review: Teachable Moments
summary: College teaching has become a pickup job, like driving for Uber, for small stipends and little or no guarantee of permanence.. In the fall of 2005, I was looking for a full-time, tenure-track job teaching undergraduates. I had just received my doctorate in English, had three or four articles published in respectable academic journals and had taught a modest array of courses as a graduate assistant and adjunct professor. I heard about two positions opening up at a middle-tier institution 120 miles from my home, and so in an attempt to boost my chances of getting one of them, I applied to teach two sections of English 101. I had a menial job and a family to support, so the adjunct work would have to be done on the side. Twice a week, for 15 weeks, I rose at 4:30 a.m., drove two hours to teach two classes at 8:00 and 9:40, then drove back to put in full eight-hour days at my regular job. I graded unreadable papers late into the night and communicated with my wife and daughters only intermittently. I gained weight from all the M&Ms and potato chips I ate mainly to stay awake on the interstate, and spent a large portion of the tiny stipend the school paid me on gas. But the students were terrific, I loved teaching them, and most of them, I felt, enjoyed and profited from my instruction.

title: Joe Biden's Last Ride

summary: The only ones using ObamaCare now are the poor and those with new or chronic pre-existing conditions. Jenkins, Jr.'s "ObamaCare Is Popular Because It Failed" (Business World, April 27): ObamaCare coverage for my family of five was about $1,600 a month with a $12,000 annual deductible. I switched to a Christian health-care sharing ministry in 2014 at $450 a month with a $7,500 deductible, about what my private insurance was before ObamaCare.

title: Joe Biden Is No Threat to President Trump

title: America's History Censors Imitate ISIS in Ignorance

Bordewich's "Even George Washington May Be Erased From Our Past" (op-ed, April 27): In 2014 and 2015 the world watched in horror and disbelief as ISIS destroyed priceless antiquities and cultural heritage sites in the Middle East because they conflicted with ISIS's ideological and historical perspectives. Is there really any difference with that and what is generally occurring today in much of America and specifically in San Francisco? The significant historical ignorance of the instigators and adjudicators also rubs salt into an open wound.

title: U.S. Needs a Private-Public Partnership on 5G Research
summary: President Trump should convene a meeting of tech CEOs and government R&D entities like Darpa and challenge them to build the strategy and team to beat global challengers in the 5G space.. William A. Galston's "China's Subsidized Conquest of Trade" (Politics & Ideas, April 24) is an eye opener, but I take issue with his key points. The relationship between Chinese firms and the state is their path to dominance, and it's folly for the U.S. to press for reform. President Trump has pointed to public-private partnerships as a mechanism for growth. That's exactly what is needed in the 5G race. He should convene a meeting of tech CEOs and government R&D entities like Darpa and challenge them to build the strategy and team to beat global challengers in the 5G space. Then create a virtual company to focus American ingenuity. That's exactly how Airbus competes with Boeing.

summary: The fair brings together a compelling mix of established and emerging artists-and Frieze-goers can even become portrait subjects themselves. Since 2013-the fair's second year in New York-Zwirner has opted to show only solo and two-artist exhibitions at Frieze. This year, the gallery's booth pairs rising art world star Harold Ancart, whose Public Art Fund commission titled Subliminal Standard debuted today at Cadman Plaza Park, and conceptual artist and photographer Christopher Williams. Both artists' works were created specifically for the fair. Ancart, whose paintings and sculptures often take the natural world on as subjects, debuts paintings of larger-than-life matchsticks. Williams is known for his work examining the role of photography in our post-industrial society; his Frieze presentation includes five new photographs adapting and restaging his earlier work.

title: A Long-Distance Renovation in a Gentrifying Piece of London
summary: Thanks to 3-D imaging, email and lots of digital photos, this family oversaw a complete renovation of their home in Peckham while living in Budapest.

title: A Long-Distance Renovation in a Gentrifying Piece of London
summary: Using 3-D imaging, email and lots of digital photos, this family oversaw a complete renovation of their home in Peckham, while living in Budapest. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: CEOs in Health Care Discuss Challenges of Artificial Intelligence
summary: Novartis CEO Vas Narasimhan said he is skeptical that AI can keep up with fast-changing treatments for complex disease like cancer. Technology is reshaping health care, from pharmaceutical research to detecting opioid addiction, but the magnitude and pace of change isn't always as dramatic as some had hoped a few years ago, industry leaders said at The Wall Street Journal Health Forum on Tuesday.

title: How Not to Bribe College Basketball Coaches
summary: The alleged bribery of top collegiate players and coaches sounds like a slick operation. But an ongoing federal trial shows that ineptness and low comedy were sprinkled in liberally with the cash.. The suite at the Cosmopolitan Hotel in Las Vegas looked like the set of a heist film: iridescent blue light cast shadows across low-slung couches, where three men in suits made deals. One by one, college basketball coaches came through. Some left with stacks of cash and agreements to steer star players to the men, who said they were starting a sports-management company.

title: CVS Shares Are on the Mend
summary: Strong results and cheap valuation should push shares higher. Much to the relief of CVS Health investors, good things still happen to cheap stocks.

title: Congestion Pricing Could Give Lift to Some Home Values
summary: Planned fees aimed at easing traffic in Manhattan will likely edge up residential prices in the targeted zone, study shows, but it may be a bumpy ride for other properties. Congestion pricing won't make only driving in New York City more expensive. Research suggests it also could boost residential real-estate prices inside the pricing zone.

title: Ronan Farrow Scoops Up Lower East Side Penthouse for $5.65 Million
summary: The journalist is known for his work exposing sexual harassment allegations against former Hollywood producer. Ronan Farrow, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist whose work helped catalyze the #MeToo sexual harassment movement, has purchased a $5.65 million penthouse in New York, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: 'He Should Go Back to Connecticut.' Barclays CEO Battles Activist Over Bank's Future.
summary: Resume Subscription. Jes Staley runs one of the last full-service banks left in Europe that compete with Wall Street. The way the 62-year-old American banker sees it, his restructuring of U.K.-based Barclays PLC has primed it to take on the likes of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Morgan Stanley .

title: Clorox's Turn to Leave a Mess in Consumer Goods Business
summary: Clorox shares are lagging peers like Procter & Gamble, but the entire household goods industry is facing challenges. Clorox is taking its turn in the household goods doghouse.

title: Venezuelans Clash as Small Group of Troops Joins Guaidó Opposition
summary: Thousands of Venezuelans clash in the streets with pro-government forces after the opposition leader's audacious call to oust President Maduro. CARACAS, Venezuela-Thousands of Venezuelans clashed in the streets with pro-government forces following an audacious call by opposition leader Juan Guaidó to join him and a small group of military officers in overthrowing President Nicolás Maduro's government.

title: Amid Cost-Cutting, MTA Grapples With Union Negotiations
summary: Transportation authority's belt-tightening efforts come into play as deadline looms for union-contract talks. New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority is clawing its way out of a looming fiscal crisis by raising fares, securing new sources of revenue and reorganizing operations. Now, it has the chance to cut into its biggest operating cost: labor.

title: Stanford Pushes Executives to Get 'Touchy Feely'
summary: University's M.B.A. program seeks new revenue by offering popular emotional intelligence course to working people; 'This isn't therapy'. Stanford University is offering one of its most popular business-school electives to people outside its elite M.B.A. program. The prerequisite? Getting in touch with your emotions.

title: Carlyle's Profit Rises; Private-Equity Funds Appreciate 5%
summary: Assets under management rose 10% to $221.5 billion in the latest quarter. Carlyle Group LP posted a stronger profit in the latest quarter as the private-equity firm recorded gains in investment income and fees, but profits that could be returned to shareholders fell as the relative recentness of its investments meant fewer fees related to gains on asset sales.

title: Designer Jeremy Scott Says Fashion Should Lighten Up
summary: Resume Subscription. This year's gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art celebrates camp, which Susan Sontag characterized as reflecting excess, extravagance, artifice and irony. Designer Jeremy Scott checks all those boxes and more.

title: WikiLeaks' Assange Sentenced to 50 Weeks in U.K. Jail
summary: A separate court will consider if Assange should be extradited to the U.S. to face charges over publication of diplomatic cables. LONDON-A British judge sentenced Julian Assange to 50 weeks in jail for skipping bail in 2012 while awaiting extradition to Sweden on sexual assault accusations, a blow to the WikiLeaks founder ahead of a hearing on whether he should be sent to the U.S. to face trial over the leak of classified documents almost a decade ago.

title: Ten Minutes Is All You Need for Nick Hornby's Latest Creation
summary: Web videos inspired the novelist and screenwriter to create 'State of the Union,' a new 10-minute-per-episode series from SundanceTV at the vanguard of experiments in short-form entertainment. Streaming services, online platforms and mobile apps have already changed the way we watch entertainment. Now they are driving artistic creation, too.

title: Government Could Run Out of Cash in Second Half, Treasury Says
summary: Agency urges Congress to act promptly to raise the federal borrowing limit. WASHINGTON-The U.S. government risks not being able to pay its bills on time later this summer or fall unless Congress acts to raise the federal borrowing limit, the Treasury Department said Wednesday.

title: Climate Changes as Firms Heed Investors on Social Issues
summary: Once-reluctant companies bend to shareholder demands on the environment and other hot-button topics. The largest U.S. companies are beginning to pay heed to the demands of investors focused on environmental and social issues, a shift for shareholders long relegated to the sidelines.

summary: Resume Subscription. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Check back closer to the market open for an updated list.

title: U.S. Private Sector Surpasses Expectations in April
summary: The April additions to private payrolls were up from a seasonally-adjusted 151,000 jobs added in March. The U.S. private sector added 275,000 jobs in April, according to the ADP National Employment Report released Wednesday, a far greater number than analysts expected.

title: This Is What Time Gayle King Sets Her Alarm
summary: The CBS This Morning co-host shares what's on her phone, from what time she wakes up each morning to the texts she received about that R. Kelly interview. First app checked in the morning and the last before bedtime: SleepWatch-you can see how much sleep you got. Before bed, I check email or text.

title: Karen Elson on Why Modeling Should Have a Chaperone System
summary: When the Nashville-based model and singer-songwriter was a teenage newcomer, she slept on a mattress on the floor of a Paris apartment. See the shoot here, and read interviews with Alek Wek, Amber Valletta and Gemma Ward.

title: The Secret History of a New York Power Spot
summary: Lorne Michaels was a regular. Malcolm Gladwell wrote his books there. Now Keith McNally's bistro Pastis-a power nexus of the Meatpacking District until its 2014 shuttering-is back. Restaurateur Keith McNally's beloved bistro Pastis anchored New York City's Meatpacking District for nearly 15 years before its doors closed in 2014. After a five-year hiatus, McNally re-opens the restaurant this month with a new partner, Stephen Starr. McNally (who closed the original space because the landlord threatened to triple the rent) says he wanted to rebuild the restaurant two years ago, but the deal fell through when McNally's business partner dropped out. Starr, an award-winning restaurateur, offered a level of funding and operational savvy that McNally, who suffered a stroke in 2017, felt could revive a restaurant that many consider to be an institution. McNally describes the new Pastis, where his 34-year-old son, Harry, will join the team, just as it ever was: "An attractive French brasserie open for breakfast, lunch and dinner serving wonderful food at reasonable prices." While the old Pastis was open until 3 a.m. on weekends, the new Pastis will finish last call at 2 a.m. Having opened and closed his share of Manhattan restaurants since 1980 (Pastis is his 15th establishment), McNally doesn't romanticize either incarnation. "No restaurant is vital," he says. Starr, who is opening his 39th restaurant, expresses greater optimism. "Pastis," he says, "is forever." Here, a look at the restaurant's past and present.

title: Post Office Boss Ponders Cutting Mail Delivery to Five Days. Congress Balks.
summary: Republicans, Democrats oppose idea that would save billions of dollars as agency tries to shift to more package deliveries. The head of the U.S. Postal Service floated a new proposal to shore up the agency's finances: deliver mail five days a week while expanding package delivery to seven.

title: CBS Embraces Strategy of Making Shows for Its Rivals
summary: About a quarter of CBS-produced shows this year are for other platforms, from Netflix to Disney+. Liz Feldman created what she thought would be a perfect Netflix show: a dark comedy about a woman struggling with grief and anger over the hit-and-run death of her husband and its effect on her family.

title: Google's Search Business Needs More Answers
summary: Lack of visibility into advertising business leaves investors flummoxed. Even in the best of times, Google has never been an easy business to figure out. In times like these, the company's opacity has taken on an extra cost.

title: Cloud Data Specialist Snowflake Picks New Chief
summary: Board taps Frank Slootman to lead fast-growing software startup, valued at $4 billion, for its 'next phase'. A fast-growing Silicon Valley unicorn is putting a new chief in charge.

title: Private Equity-Backed Crunch Fitness Weighs Options
summary: The gym chain engaged Citigroup to explore strategic alternatives including a sale, said people familiar with the matter. Gym chain Crunch Fitness is flexing for a new owner, said people familiar with the matter.

title: Auto Dealership Stocks Rally as Firms Pivot From New Vehicles
summary: Auto retailer stocks are up 33% year-to-date, outpacing the S&P 500, as firms boost used-car operations and service departments. Stock prices for the nation's publicly traded dealership groups have rallied in recent months, a sign of Wall Street's greater confidence in the ability of auto retailers to weather an expected downturn in the U.S. car market.

title: Stock Markets in Europe Break Records for Calm and Quiet
summary: A leading European stock index has barely budged for 17 trading days in a row, breaking the previous streak set in 1993. In Europe, markets have hit their summer lull early-very early. As with markets in the U.S. and elsewhere, this very stability could be a dangerous thing for investors desperately hunting for returns.

title: Raine Group Leads $70 Million Investment in Ad-Tech Firm VideoAmp
summary: Former Tribune Media chief Peter Liguori joins the board. Advertising technology firm VideoAmp Inc. has raised $70 million, suggesting that investors still have confidence in the challenged category.

title: The Noisiest Parts of the Plane
summary: Taking a decibel meter onto several different jets finds a difference between the front and the back, and even the window and aisle. Besides skinny seats, slim lavatories and overstuffed overhead bins, here's another reason to loathe the back of the airplane: It's noisier than the front.

title: As Retiree Health-Care Bills Mount, States Have a Solution: Stop Paying
summary: Local governments are testing how far they can reduce health benefits for their retirees. North Carolina corrections official Charles Johnson will soon lose a major perk he can offer recruits when the state ends a promise to pay health-care bills once workers retire.

title: Marvel's Mightiest Zeros: How the Avengers Broke Box Office Records
summary: 'Endgame' is already No. 10 on the all-time box office list after six days. Here's some of what happened along the way.. Everyone in Hollywood expected that "Avengers: Endgame" was going to be a hit. But the movie's ultimate opening-weekend performance crushed all competition past and present with the force of Thor's hammer.

title: Qualcomm Profit Will Likely Sag, but All Eyes Are on Apple Windfall
summary: Analysts and investors want to know how much Qualcomm will make in iPhone royalties after settlement. Qualcomm Inc. is scheduled to report fiscal second-quarter earnings after the market closes Wednesday. Analysts expect sliding revenue and profit, but their focus has shifted to the future after the chip maker settled a long-running legal dispute with Apple Inc. in mid-April, sending its shares up more than 50%. Here's what to expect:

title: Investors Await Clues on Fed's Rate Pause, Policy Outlook
summary: The discussions could help to define how officials react to surprises on growth, inflation and hiring in the months ahead. Federal Reserve officials are poised to leave interest rates unchanged at their two-day meeting ending Wednesday, and the debate could center on what it would take for them to move off the sidelines.

title: Upward Move on Key Market Rate Could Bring Fed Response
summary: Some analysts think the central bank might need bigger technical tweaks to keep control over short-term rates. The Federal Reserve's tool kit for controlling interest rates is facing a challenge that could prompt changes in the mechanics of how the central bank influences the economy.

title: Brands Reach for a Gaming Console
summary: Bud Light is the latest global company to use video games to target young consumers. Global brands are dipping a toe into the surreal world of fantasy gaming. The trend shows the need for new tactics to reach young consumers.

title: Mueller Objected to Barr's Summary of Report on Russia
summary: Special counsel said attorney general 'did not fully capture the context, nature and substance' of findings on Trump and Russia. WASHINGTON-Special counsel Robert Mueller told Attorney General William Barr in March that his four-page letter summarizing the findings of the Russia investigation failed to "fully capture" the team's work and threatened the public's confidence in the results of the probe, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: McGraw-Hill to Merge With Rival Textbook Publisher
summary: Deal with Cengage would create second-largest U.S. provider of textbooks and higher-education materials. McGraw-Hill and Cengage plan to merge in a deal that would create the second-largest provider of college textbooks and other higher-education materials in the country.

title: Barr, Democrats Clash Over Mueller Report
summary: Attorney general won't appear before a scheduled Thursday House hearing. WASHINGTON-Attorney General William Barr criticized Robert Mueller's decision not to reach a conclusion about whether President Trump obstructed justice during a contentious hearing that laid bare a rift between him and the special counsel over the politically charged investigation.

title: Japan's New Emperor Ascends to Throne
summary: It was the first abdication by a Japanese emperor in more than 200 years. TOKYO-Japan's new emperor pledged to be a symbol of peace and national unity in his first public remarks after taking the throne.

title: UNC Charlotte Campus Shooting Leaves at Least Two Dead
summary: A male suspect has been taken into custody. Two people were killed and four others were injured Tuesday when a man opened fire on the campus of the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, according to the head of campus police.

title: Prosecutors Sought Chinese Bank Records in North Korea Probe
summary: Ruling under the Patriot Act could cut off banks' access to U.S. correspondent accounts if they don't comply. WASHINGTON-A U.S. federal judge ordered three Chinese banks to provide documents sought by a grand jury and federal prosecutors investigating a Hong Kong-based front company for North Korea's nuclear program, according to an opinion unsealed late Tuesday.

title: Apple Posts Declines in Profit, Revenue as iPhone Sales Fall 17%
summary: Overall revenue and profit decline, though results exceed expectations; shares climb in after-hours trading. Apple Inc. posted its first back-to-back drop in quarterly sales and profit in more than two years, but the tech titan reported strength beyond its struggling iPhone business and said a sharp downturn in China showed signs of easing.

title: Wynn Resorts Cleared to Open Casino as Regulators Levy $35 Million Fine
summary: CEO Matt Maddox is personally fined $500,000. Massachusetts gambling regulators said casino giant Wynn Resorts Ltd. can retain its license to open a new casino in the state but sharply rebuked Chief Executive Matt Maddox over his leadership of the company amid sexual-misconduct allegations against founder and former CEO Steve Wynn.

title: Judge Throws Out a Conviction Against Ex-Penn State President
summary: Prosecutors have the option to retry case tied to Jerry Sandusky scandal within three months. HARRISBURG, Pa.-A federal judge threw out former Penn State President Graham Spanier's misdemeanor child-endangerment conviction on Tuesday, less than a day before he was due to turn himself in to begin serving a jail sentence.

title: Judge Approves Deal Spelling Out Oversight of Elon Musk's Tweets
summary: Order lists financial milestones, other events that Tesla chief executive can't tweet about without preapproval. A federal judge approved a new deal clarifying how Tesla Inc. must oversee Elon Musk's use of Twitter , an outcome that erases the risk its chief executive would be punished for violating the original agreement.

title: Government to File Complaint Over Alleged Bribery by Mallinckrodt Unit to Drive Drug Sales
summary: News of whistleblower lawsuits on muscular-dystrophy medication sends stock down 16%. Shares of drugmaker Mallinckrodt Plc fell 16% Tuesday after news reports that the federal government is intervening in a pair of lawsuits that allege its subsidiary bribed doctors to drive sales of a pricey multiple-sclerosis drug.

title: Wisconsin High Court Restores 82 Appointees Confirmed in Lame-Duck Session
summary: Order marks a victory for Republicans, setback for Democratic Gov. Tony Evers. A divided Wisconsin Supreme Court has restored 82 appointees of then-Gov. Scott Walker who were confirmed during a lame-duck legislative session, handing a victory to Republicans and defeat to Democratic Gov. Tony Evers.

title: Suspect in California Synagogue Shooting Pleads Not Guilty
summary: Prosecutors say he was arrested with some 50 unused bullets in his car. The accused gunman in a deadly attack on a synagogue outside San Diego pleaded not guilty in his first court appearance, as prosecutors said they would weigh the death penalty for hate-crime charges.

title: SoftBank Invests $1 Billion in Colombian Delivery Startup Rappi
summary: SoftBank in March said it planned to invest $5 billion in Latin America. SoftBank Group Corp. has made a $1 billion investment in Rappi Inc., a South American on-demand delivery company, one of several investments that it has made in the category.

title: Union Square Ventures Rides Returns to New Set of Funds
summary: New York firm also names new partners as one of its founders steps back from his role as a managing member of the firm's funds. Union Square Ventures, a backer of well-known startups such as Twitter Inc., Coinbase Inc. and Stripe Inc., has raised a new pair of funds, showing limited partners' confidence in the firm's strong track record.

title: New York City Homeless Shelter Population Could Rise by 5,000, Report Says
summary: Coalition for the Homeless warns that 65,000 people could be affected by 2022 because of the lack of shelters and permanent housing. New York City's homeless shelter population could rise by more than 5,000 people during the next three years, according to a new report.
